instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Hi, here I have this Mac with Green and Orange light, but no power.
Has no signs of liquid. 
<TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> replaced as it was blown.
After a few checks, I found that <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing.
I replaced
clock chip <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and Y1915 just to make sure it was OK.
Still no power.

I removed <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is up - 3.3V.
I solder <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR>, the line goes.

Furthermore, I read that it may be a dead CPU.
I Just wonder if anyone has a better idea of what is happening here, please.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at L7430.

Do you get steady L7520 voltage, when <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR> is removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
L7520 5.43V steady when <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR> removed
L7430 0.269 diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Resolder <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR>.
Remove <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> and check if L7430 voltage appears.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: After resolder <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR> and remove <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> voltage on L7430 cycle 2 time for less than a sec and stays on 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Test changing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.
May need to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: Both replaced and still no fan spinning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> and check again L7430 voltage.
Keep in place <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: After remove the <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> the voltage on L7420 is 1.20V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Do you mean <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>?
Board stays on, with CPU core voltage present?
Did you test USB activity?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Yes, I mean <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>.
CPU core voltage not present.
USB has power, but no activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
With and without  <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>, the voltages are.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> - 0.05V
<SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: So you have steady 1.2V at L7420, but <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> stays low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: yes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
I realized we talk about L7439 in fact.
So board stays in S3, but fails to pass into S0.
Resolder <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> for next tests.

Seems that your board is in the "cycling two tines", the worst scenario.
L7310/20 and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message: L7310/20 and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
Test if simething change in SMC bypass mode.

Very likely PCH problem.
Check all voltages from page 11.
If all present, try heating PCH/CPU with quality flux.
I recently solved same problem caused by accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
On SMC bypass mode, fan cycles twice and stop.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.10V (Cycle to 3.3V for a sec if press power button)
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 0V (Cycle to 0.99V for a sec if press power button)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air
threads.message:
"Check all voltages from page 11."
There are several series coils and 0 ohm resistors; don't you want to check all them???
